DOCNAME: CASE OF BRUALLA GÓMEZ DE LA TORRE v. SPAIN
CONCLUSION: No violation of Article 6 - Right to a fair trial (Article 6 - Civil proceedings;Article 6-1 - Fair hearing)
TEXT: CARDINAL . PERSON was born in DATE and lives in GPE . At the material time , she practised as a lawyer ( procurador ) in LOC owned by an insurance company and to the tenancy of which she considered that she had succeeded on the death of her father .

CARDINAL . At some point in DATE the insurance company brought an action in ORG for termination of the lease , arguing that the applicant could not succeed to her father ’s rights under it . On DATE the insurance company ’s action was dismissed . It appealed .
CARDINAL . On DATE the Madrid Audiencia provincial reversed the impugned decision , holding that the applicant could not succeed to her father ’s rights under the lease .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant gave notice to the Audiencia provincial of her intention to appeal to ORG . On DATE the Audiencia provincial formally noted that notice of appeal had been given ( “ se tiene por preparado el recurso ” ) and on DATE it summoned the parties to appear before ORG to enter the appeal within DATE time - limit laid down by LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . In the meantime PERSON no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL of DATE ( “ Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ” ) , which made urgent changes to various court procedures , had come into force on DATE ( DATE after its publication in ORG ) . It amended certain provisions of LAW , in particular those governing the conditions of admissibility of appeals to ORG in proceedings concerning leases of urban property ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG delivered a decision in which it construed the transitional provisions of LAW no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL . With respect to appeals of which notice had been given to the courts below before the entry into force of that PERSON but which had not been entered with ORG , it held :

“ In view of the silence of the [ transitional ] provision [ no . CARDINAL ] or its failure to deal with the question , the new procedure shall apply in full in the case referred to above , and that makes it necessary to refer to LAW of CARDINAL DATE promulgating LAW , a provision which is of general application . ”
CARDINAL . NORP On DATE , within DATE period allowed by the Audiencia provincial ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , the applicant entered her appeal with ORG .

CARDINAL . In its decision ( auto ) of CARDINAL DATE ORG held at the outset that , pursuant to transitional provision no . CARDINAL ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , PERSON no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL applied to cases such as the one before it in which an appeal had not been entered until after that PERSON had come into force , even if notice of intention to lodge the appeal had been given beforehand . It went on to find that the DATE amount of rent payable under the lease in question was MONEY , which was less than the minimum amount ( MONEY ) required under the new legislation for an appeal to lie to ORG . That being so , the applicant ’s appeal had to be declared inadmissible in accordance with LAW in conjunction with CARDINAL of ORG , both as amended by PERSON no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ( see paragraphs CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE PERSON lodged an amparo appeal with ORG on the basis of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . On DATE , at the request of the applicant , ORG ordered a stay of execution of the FAC provincial ’s judgment .

CARDINAL . Referring in particular to its own case - law on ORG interpretation of transitional provision no . CARDINAL of Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , ORG , declining to adopt the opinion of ORG , dismissed the applicant ’s amparo appeal on DATE . It reiterated that the interpretation of transitional provisions was a matter for the ordinary courts and held that the criteria relied on by ORG in the impugned decision for declaring the appeal on points of law inadmissible were both reasoned and reasonable . That court ’s construction of the provisions of the new legislation was neither arbitrary nor ill - founded . The fact that in its decision it had relied on a provision that had come into force after notice of appeal had been given but before the appeal had been entered with ORG was not decisive as no constitutional provision prohibited amending the appeals procedure so long as the right to a fair hearing was protected .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § QUANTITY of the LAW provides :

“ Everyone has the right to effective protection by the judges and courts in the exercise of his rights and his legitimate interests ; in no circumstances may there be any denial of defence rights . ”
CARDINAL . Transitional provision no . CARDINAL of Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL of DATE , which amended LAW , provides :

“ No ordinary appeal or appeal on points of law shall lie against a judicial decision in a civil matter delivered after this PERSON comes into force unless the decision satisfies the conditions laid down in this PERSON for that purpose .

With regard to pending appeals on points of law whose admissibility has not yet been determined , ORG of ORG ... may declare an appeal inadmissible for the reasons set out in LAW , as amended by this PERSON . In that connection , both the grounds of appeal and the limits referred to in rule CARDINAL of sub - paragraph CARDINAL of that Article shall be governed by the legislation in force at the time of the entering ( interposición ) of the appeal ... ”
CARDINAL . Before Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL came into force , the relevant provisions governing notice of appeal to ORG ( preparación del recurso ) read as follows :

“ Notice of appeal shall be given in writing to the judicial authority which delivered the impugned decision within DATE from DATE after the decision was served . The notice of appeal shall contain a statement [ by the appellant ] of his intention to appeal to ORG , a brief summary of the conditions that have to be satisfied and a request that the appeal be acknowledged as having been made in time and in the prescribed form , that the original case file , with the appeal file where appropriate , be sent to ORG and that the parties be summoned to appear .
If no notice of intention to appeal has been given within DATE , the judgment or decision shall become final . ”
“ Notice of intention to appeal shall be given by the lawyers ( procurador and abogado ) representing the appellant ... ”

“ If notice of intention to appeal has been given in accordance with the preceding CARDINAL provisions and concerns a decision against which an appeal lies , ORG shall acknowledge that notice of intention to appeal has been given ( tendrá por preparado [ el recurso ] ) and within DATE shall send the original case file and the appeal file to ORG .
At the same time the parties shall be summoned to appear before ORG within not DATE . However , only the appellant shall be required to appear in order to enter the appeal on points of law .
“ A party which has given notice of intention to appeal shall enter the appeal with ORG within DATE from the date on which [ the parties ] were summoned [ to appear ] .
If the appeal is not entered within that time , the judgment or decision shall become final . ”
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL governs the entering of appeals on points of law . As amended by Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , it is worded as follows :

“ CARDINAL . After the case file has been forwarded by ORG , it shall be sent to the reporting judge , who shall consider it and submit it to the ORG for it to decide on how to deal with it in accordance with the following rules :

( CARDINAL ) ORG shall ... declare an appeal inadmissible where , notwithstanding that notice of appeal has been given , the ORG finds that Articles CARDINAL and DATE have not been complied with , or where the provisions relied on have no relevance to the matters at issue in the appeal , or where rectification of a defect has been ordered but the case file shows that it has not been carried out .

( CARDINAL ) An appeal shall be declared inadmissible ... where the amount in issue has not been calculated in accordance with the applicable rules or where the ORG holds that the amount is less than the amounts mentioned in LAW . ”
CARDINAL . As amended by PERSON no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , section CARDINAL of ORG provides :

“ No appeal shall lie against judgments delivered by the Audiencia provincial sitting as an appellate court except where they concern disputes over leases of commercial property for which the agreed rent exceeds MONEY , in which case an appeal on points of law may be made on the grounds and in accordance with the procedures laid down in LAW . ”
Before Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL was enacted the relevant minimum sum was MONEY .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the royal decree of DATE promulgating LAW provides :

“ For appeals on points of law entered ( interpuestos ) before DATE , the procedure laid down by the legislation currently in force shall apply ; for [ appeals entered ] after that date the procedure laid down by the new legislation shall apply , even if notice of appeal was given before that date . ”

CARDINAL . In a judgment ( no . CARDINAL ) of DATE , which concerned a case similar to the instant CARDINAL , ORG laid down the principles governing the application ratione temporis of PERSON no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL of DATE . It stated , in particular , that ORG interpretation of transitional provision no . CARDINAL , though justified on the facts , should not be considered the only construction possible . It also explained that the term “ interposición ” used in transitional provision no . CARDINAL referred to the entering of an appeal on points of law with ORG and not the giving of notice of appeal to the Audiencia provincial . Consequently , the system prior to the amendment introduced by LAW no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL applied to giving notice of appeal and the new system to entering an appeal . ORG also referred to its settled case - law to the effect that LAW did not afford parties to proceedings any guarantee that the appeals system established by law would not be modified , so long as the parties’ right to a “ fair hearing ” was not infringed and decisions declaring appeals inadmissible were not unjustified or ill - founded . Lastly , it pointed out with regard to transitional provisions that , in accordance with LAW , it was for the ordinary courts alone to determine the applicable rule . In conclusion , ORG dismissed the amparo appeal .

CARDINAL . Earlier , in a decision of DATE concerning amparo appeal no . CARDINAL , ORG had considered the issue of the applicability ratione temporis of the second transitional provision of PERSON no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL of DATE . That provision also amended LAW but , unlike PERSON no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , provided : “ After the proceedings to which they refer have ended , appeals to ORG which have been entered ( interpuestos ) shall be conducted in accordance with the amendments made by this PERSON . ” In that case the appellants had given notice of appeal in accordance with the provisions of legislation previously in force and had then entered the appeal in accordance with the provisions of the new legislation , the substantive requirements of which were , however , no different from those of the earlier legislation . ORG held that while the word “ interponer ” appeared to refer to the formal entering of the appeal , the reference to the ending of the proceedings suggested , however , that the legislature ’s intention had not been to alter the rules applicable to appeals of which notice had been given but which had yet to be entered . ORG held that ORG interpretation of that transitional provision could not be regarded as unfounded , still less as unreasonable , and that the decision as to which legislation governed the entering of the appeal – in that case the legislation previously in force – had not been deficient constitutionally . ORG accordingly allowed the amparo appeal , holding that the appellants had been the victims of excessive formalism .
